factoid: Véra decided that Pierre ought to be entertained with conversation about the French embassy.
Véra began entertaining Pierre accordingly.
Berg decided that masculine conversation was required.
Berg interrupted Berg's wife's remarks.
Berg touched on the question of the war with Austria.
Berg unconsciously jumped from the general subject to personal considerations about proposals made to Berg to take part in the Austrian campaign.
Berg unconsciously jumped from the general subject to personal considerations about the reasons why Berg had declined the proposals.
The conversation was very incoherent.
Véra was angry at the intrusion of the masculine element.
Véra and Berg felt with satisfaction that their evening had begun very well.
The evening was like other evening parties with talk, tea, and lighted candles.
Borís arrived before long.
Borís was Berg’s old comrade.
Borís treated Berg and Véra with a shade of condescension and patronage.
A lady arrived with the colonel.
The general arrived after the lady and the colonel.
The Rostóvs arrived after the general.
The party became exactly like all other evening parties after the arrivals.
Berg and Véra could not repress their smiles of satisfaction at the sight of movement in Berg and Véra's drawing room.
Berg and Véra could not repress their smiles of satisfaction at the sound of the disconnected talk.
Berg and Véra could not repress their smiles of satisfaction at the rustling of dresses.
Berg and Véra could not repress their smiles of satisfaction at the bowing and scraping.
Everything was just as everybody always has it.
The general admired the apartment.
The general patted Berg on the shoulder.
The general superintended the setting out of the table for boston with parental authority.
The general sat down by Count Ilyá Rostóv.
Count Ilyá Rostóv was the most important guest next to the general.
The old people sat with the old.
The young people sat with the young.
The hostess sat at the tea table.
Cakes stood in a silver cake basket on the tea table.
The cakes were exactly the same kind as those at the Panins' party.
Everything was just as everything was everywhere else.
Pierre was one of the principal guests.
Pierre sat down to play boston with Count Rostóv, the general, and the colonel.
Pierre was directly facing Natásha at the card table.
Pierre was struck by a curious change that had come over Natásha since the ball.
Natásha was silent.
Natásha was less pretty than at the ball.
Natásha was redeemed from plainness by Natásha's look of gentle indifference to everything around.
Pierre thought "What's the matter with her?" while glancing at Natásha.
Natásha was sitting by Natásha's sister at the tea table.
Natásha made some reply to Borís without looking at Pierre.
Borís sat down beside Natásha.
Pierre played out a whole suit and took five tricks.
Pierre heard greetings and the steps of someone who entered the room while Pierre was picking up Pierre's tricks.
Pierre glanced again at Natásha.
Pierre asked himself "What has happened to Natásha?" with greater surprise.
Prince Andrew was standing before Natásha.
Prince Andrew was saying something to Natásha with a look of tender solicitude.
Natásha raised her head.
Natásha was looking up at Prince Andrew.
Natásha was flushed.
Natásha was trying to master her rapid breathing.
The bright glow of some inner fire that had been suppressed was again alight in Natásha.
Natásha was completely transformed.
Natásha had become what she had been at the ball.
Prince Andrew went up to Pierre.
Pierre noticed a new and youthful expression in Prince Andrew's face.
Pierre changed places several times during the game.
Pierre sat with Pierre's back to Natásha at times.
Pierre sat facing Natásha at times.
During the whole of the six rubbers, Pierre watched Natásha and Prince Andrew.
Pierre thought "Something very important is happening between them."
A feeling that was both joyful and painful agitated Pierre.
The feeling made Pierre neglect the game.
After six rubbers, the general got up.
The general said that it was no use playing like that.
Pierre was released after the general got up.
Natásha was talking with Sónya and Borís.
Véra was saying something to Prince Andrew with a subtle smile.
Pierre went up to Prince Andrew.
Pierre asked whether the group was talking secrets.
Pierre sat down beside Prince Andrew, Natásha, and Sónya.
Véra noticed Prince Andrew’s attentions to Natásha.
Véra decided that subtle allusions to tender passion were absolutely necessary at a real evening party.
Véra began a conversation with Prince Andrew when Prince Andrew was alone.
The conversation was about feelings in general and about Natásha.
Véra considered Prince Andrew to be an intellectual guest.
Véra felt Véra had to employ diplomatic tact.
When Pierre went up to Prince Andrew, Natásha, and Véra, Pierre noticed Véra was being carried away by self-satisfied talk.
Prince Andrew seemed embarrassed, a thing that rarely was his.
